text: How can you begin to understand the choppy waters of web three? Welcome to Cryptoverse, a new real vision live show. Here we focus on the big, interesting, and promising developments in crypto. speaker: A
text: Thanks so much for having me.

speaker: C
text: It's a pleasure to have you here. We were talking a little bit off camera. You have an interesting background. Tell us about how you got into the web three space.

speaker: A
text: Absolutely. So I began my career working at HuffPost, where I learned about the problems that creators face getting remunerated for the content that they create online because of, among other things, the double spend problem. I started getting obsessed with payments. Started a startup that focused on getting creators online, paid for their work that was decentralized before there was really the technology to back it up. Learned about Ethereum from going to one of the first Ethereum meetups in New York as a result of my fascination with payments, accidentally bumped into Joe Lubin, Andrew keys, Christian Lundquist was just blown away by the early folks around the Ethereum movement. It was clear to me that even though I didn't have the technical skills to diligence the code myself, I could diligence the people. And they were some of the smartest people I'd ever met. And so I joined the circus and became chief marketing officer at Consensys pretty early in 2016.

speaker: C
text: It's really interesting to me because you'd already identified the key challenge that was attempting to be addressed in some ways. Obviously, digital assets have a broad array of applications. But you saw this sense of the aggregation of wealth to the network owners, folks like Facebook and Twitter who actually owned the web, two based networks, and rather than the content creators themselves who were creating the content. Talk a little bit about that dichotomy, what you saw there. You talked about this idea of remuneration of fancy word for how do you get paid for your work? Talk a little bit about that split that you identified and how that's still relevant today.

speaker: A
text: Sure. So, actually, if you look in the original source code of the web, there's such a thing as a 402 error. You might be familiar with a 404 error, but you've never seen a 402 error because it's payment missing. And the reason that error code exists is because the original architects of the web intended for there to be a native payments layer inside of the Internet. They didn't get around to making it. And so when the companies that we call the web two platforms, the Facebooks of the world, started trying to, Googles of the world, started trying to figure out how to monetize, the only way to monetize was using payments that were a layer apart from the Internet and aggregating attention and charging payments for that attention. So you get the classic web two advertising based business model that someone like Jaron Lanier calls bummer behavior modifications, engines for rent. And that's how we ended up where we are. And so there's a way in which web three isn't something completely new, so much as a restoration of the original values that went into building the web. And that means native payments such that you don't need to pay the piper, these giant intermediaries, in order to connect, let's say, a piece of content or really anything else with its market.

speaker: C
text: Yeah, I agree with that completely. The idea that Web three is very much an evolution of web two. It's been a. A 50 year journey to get here. And you identified this key challenge with regard to web two being the problem of payments, the cost, the expense. This was something that was solved by bitcoin, this novel mechanism that Satoshi Nakamoto found for solving the double spend problem. Talk a little bit about where we are today, how you see the current state of play in the web three ecosystem.

speaker: A
text: Sure. So in 2021, we saw a giant expansion of what we call web three. And that term web three, which was. Wasn't that used before? It's been around a really long time, came to the surface. And the reason that came to the surface, there's kind of a darwinian evolution of terminology. That gets used if there's something going on that it describes really well. And so originally, when I started working in this space, most of the use cases were in some way financial. And so it made sense to call what we were doing cryptocurrency. In 2021, we see this explosion of nfts. NFT is a concept that's been around a long time, but it really explodes as web three starts to intersect. Entertainment, entertainment, media, fashion, gaming. And suddenly we have all of these non primarily currency focused use cases, and we have all of these new types of assets and new types of ownable digital objects that are flowing around that aren't primarily currencies. And we have all kinds of new people that have come into the space that aren't engineers, that aren't necessarily traders, but that come from other industries. I think that's been cool because crypto's original parents were technology and finance. So the people that we used to have in the space were people that came from technology and finance. But this technology is poised to intersect every single industry. And as it does, it's almost like a river that keeps on connecting new tributaries. We're going to intersect entertainment, gaming, fashion, art, but also real estate, also luxury, also sustainability and green tech also. We're going to intersect with what's going on in AI, and we're going to bring not just those technologies and those industries on chain, but also those people. And so in 2021, we saw a really radical growth of the types of use cases that were popular for blockchain technology and the types of people that were involved. And now, once again, we're seeing some of that exuberance, people losing money and people who put their money in centralized exchanges having big problems. And so we're seeing a regulatory tightening and scrutiny. And that's natural. We've seen that at every stage where there will be this kind of swelling of enthusiasm and excitement about the technology, something will go wrong and regulators will come in and try to identify what went wrong and create rules so that that doesn't happen again.

speaker: C
text: Yeah, I think that's very well said and very apt description of exactly what we see right now. Obviously, the risk here is that some of the regulatory, legal compliance, legislative headwinds can slow down the adoption of this technology. Thoughts on that?

speaker: A
text: That is the risk. Right. And I think it's just a matter of, I think a good regulator has the mentality of how do we protect the growth of an important new industry, especially one with the potential to drive a lot of prosperity, especially for young people in a world where a lot of economies are contracting or where growth is kind of stimulated and artificial rather than natural. This is one of the few industries that's really genuinely growing. So I think smart, well intentioned regulators are thinking, how do we continue growing this industry? How do we keep the leadership of this industry in the United States? And at the same time, how do we make sure that consumers are protected? I have a very specific perspective on this. I wrote a piece in Coindesk right after the FTX collapse, called FTX, shows the failures of c five, not DeFi. And there are a lot of great perspectives in the space about whether there should even exist. But if these agencies exist and if they have a mandate in good faith to try to protect consumers and to try to foster growth, then perhaps they should consider regulating in accordance with how centralized a platform is. Because the more centralized a platform is, like a centralized exchange, the more that that entity can obfuscate what they're doing or any kinds of risks they're taking with consumer funds. So that was my proposal in this article. If we're going to be regulating this industry, I don't know whether I think that should happen or shouldn't. But here we are. We've got these regulatory bodies. They have this mandate. Perhaps they should start with c five. And we're seeing that. Right? So you see this really interesting bill, the blockchain Regulatory Clarity act, from the co chairs of the Congressional Blockchain Caucus. Obviously, you have no idea whether something like that would actually get through, but it establishes that there should be different rules for custodial services, decentralized services, versus a DeFi service like a DAx that's non custodial. And I think.

speaker: C
text: Let me ask you this. speaker: A

And you know, I don't think that's the most thoughtful, nuanced perspective. But you also see the opposite, right? You see the co chairs of the blockchain caucus differentiating c five from DeFi. You see Ted Cruz passing this bill that would perhaps prohibit or proposing a bill that would perhaps prohibit the Fed from issuing a CBDC. So I think that knowledge exists. speaker: C

I mean, there have been all kinds of attacks, replay attacks, flaws in the code, flash loans, all types of attacks that we've seen on DeFi. speaker: A
text: Sure. So something like Ethereum, something like bitcoin are antifragile systems, to use the Nassim Talib terminology, right. There wouldn't be a so much value stored on the bitcoin blockchain, so much value on the Ethereum blockchain, if buyers believed that it could easily be hacked and see its value drained. And the reason for that steadfast belief is that those systems have been around for a while, and they've benefited from many attempts to attack and hack them. And so over time, those systems deserve more trust because there's just been so much money in there for so long that if someone could get it, they probably would have. And obviously it's not perfect. No one that understands anything about security would ever say, this is 100% guaranteed that no one can ever hack it. And you should be worried if you ever see something making that statement. But over time, it's battle tested. Protocols that are the most safe. And so passing a sweeping judgment on DeFi doesn't make sense because some of the protocols have been battle tested over a long time with many audits, with many attempted hacks, and some of them are newer. But what I think is preferable about DeFI over CFI is even if there's an error in the code, it's a transparent error, something could potentially fix it and find it, whereas with a centralized platform currently it's completely opaque. What they're actually doing with, let's say, consumer funds, like what happened with FTX, like what happened with a number of the other C five platforms that have collapsed. And so I think we're going to have, people are going to rightfully trust these platforms more as they're more battle tested, and then we're also going to very quickly be able to test the code bases for these platforms much better with AI. We're already seeing the evolution of new AI auditing tools to detect errors in smart contracts, and I think that's going to accelerate really quickly.

speaker: C
text: Yeah, this is a fascinating development. Tell me a little bit about that. Talk a little bit about some of the ways that you believe AI can help in terms of the security audits and securing the underlying code base.

speaker: A
text: So one of the first AI use cases that's actually been around quite a while has been copilot on GitHub, and that is a helper that allows you to write more code than you would be able to do otherwise. And it's not at a point yet where your average person, in my opinion, can just start coding without any coding knowledge. But it's going to get there and that's going to be much more trustworthy code than code purely generated by humans. And also you can have multiple different AI's and check it. And so I think we're going to see fewer errors, hacks mistakes. I think something like the Ethereum Dow hack probably wouldn't happen if a really high quality AI had audited that code base or multiple different super high quality AI's. And so I think the ability to write code really quickly in the blockchain space and the ability to audit that code much more effectively is one of the coolest benefits that we're going to see from AI plus blockchain in the super near future.

speaker: C
text: Yeah, it's an incredibly interesting topic. I want to talk a little bit about some of the UI UX issues in the space, user experience and basically user interface issues. You're someone who, as you said, does not come from a background of having been a coder, for example. And I think one of the challenges with the space today is that in many ways, some of the user interface experiences, user interface elements look as though they were written by coders. They're not written for people who don't have technical backgrounds. Talk a little bit about where you think web three is right now in terms of usability and therefore adaptability by a mass market.

speaker: A
text: Sure. So there's a fundamental trait that happens when you go from web two in terms of custodying assets to web three. And I don't think it's a real web three onboarding if you're not custodying your own assets. So when I refer to web three or web three wallets, I mean self custodial, self sovereign, offering root ownership. So you're going from a financial system where assets are fundamentally owned by someone else, and you could at any point lose access to those assets arbitrarily by some kind of regulatory body order by accident. And what we're doing with web three, with crypto, is offering people, for the first time, true individual root ownership of their digital assets. And so the onus is passing from an intermediary institution like a bank, which can easily reverse a transaction that was an error, that was made under duress, et cetera, to a system where that responsibility is on the individual to their own value, and to not make mistakes, and the consequences are real for that person. And so fundamentally, there's a shift in where the responsibility lies, which is a trade that people voluntarily make in order to have that control. And so there's a degree to which it's always going to be harder, because that burden is on the individual if they're going to root on their own assets. And I think the, the wallets, like metamask, for example, have already evolved a lot in terms of helping people learn to self custody. I think it's much easier for people to get onboarded than it was in, let's say, 2016. But that being said, I think the UX will continue to evolve and evolve as there's more demand. But the flip side is that responsibility genuinely has shifted, so there will just always be a higher burden on the user.

Which is, which is 25% or 25 of the world's largest hedge funds are onboarded and active at Coinbase. That's a big deal. It took them a year to 18 months to do the operational due diligence to satisfy themselves, and now they're actively trading. If I look at, I can almost put them on a spectrum by type of client. Hedge funds are early and active and youre right, some of them are very opportunistic. So they come and go with risk on and risk off sentiment. But its interesting as we were getting, were still progressing through this. But the worlds largest asset manager, Blackrock, made a giant investment. text: And Apollo is in the space as.

speaker: C

speaker: E
text: I mean, thats another validation at Austin.

speaker: B
text: Space and many others. And so the asset management community, generally speaking, is sort of progressively moving towards onboarding. They dont seem to be quite in the same rush as they were in sort of the massive bull market, but youre going to hear a whole bunch of new product launches coming up from clients next quarter. We had a bunch of things that were meant to have been launched in the fourth quarter of last year. Theres now been, FTX was a catastrophic first sentiment, but it made everyone double down on odd operational due diligence. Now a whole bunch of fund launches will come back to the market I think in the next quarter. Thats important. But heres the thing, the pension funds have been interested and they have really long time horizons. I think speaking for them a little bit, theres just not that many investable asset management platforms because they havent been given the thumbs up by the all boards and the Cambridges and of the track record, all the rest of it. So theres just like gaping hole between a lot of pension money that wants to get into this space and we dont have as big a bench as we should as an industry of having different options of credible asset managers that meet that hurdle. And that's where this asset management strategy for us comes into play in order to get that next wave of institutional capital into this space.

text: Well, it's interesting. speaker: E
text: Well, it basically is an initial step of the SEC setting out what its intentions are in connection with the counterparty, and the counterparty then has an opportunity to respond. I think there's so much bad actors out there that are not as transparent and not taking proactive steps to try and create transparency and manage KYC, etcetera, that need to be subject to enforcement. I just thought that that was an interesting choice without saying much more.

speaker: C
text: So what does it mean for other players in the industry? And you see this wells notice being served to what is generally viewed, at least in the space, as a good actor. speaker: E
text: Well, its quite interesting. I think if youre already a regular, if you're an exchange that is already regulated, you already have broker dealer arrangements, you already have all the sort of setup of having segregated parties involved with the exchange, different brokers, different csds, etcetera. In some ways, the position that the regulators are taking is saying, look, we want to regulate these exactly like how we regulate the securities market. Despite the fact that some of these instruments, they've gone out in the past and said they're not securities, we want to regulate them the same way. That's the general messaging. So I think for traditional institutions in some way, that could, that may not be such a bad thing because you already know how to manage such instruments. You already have all the regulatory authorizations as well. So in some ways, it's moving, you know, the industry towards those kinds of institutions that already are in place, already manage traditional financial instruments. text: Well, it's obvious that suddenly there's a real focus on all the regulatory elements associated with the industry, which I think with earlier guidance, a lot of this could have been sort of managed better. The regulators could have taken steps proactively to manage these things with them earlier, but suddenly it's happening now. So I think the industry is subject to some regulatory stress. But I think there are other elements within the digital assets industry, such as real world assets going on chain or securities institutions that are creating securities on chain products that are not going to be really impacted by this because they're going to comply with the existing regulation. In any event, they're just using the underlying technology to implement their financial transactions. So I think you have that sector that is growing, frankly, and doing really well, and there's more involvement. Digital assets. We, California that's coming up in May is very reflective of that.

speaker: E
text: Well, it's quite interesting. We have, just to give you a feel, the interest in the sector here at the firm. We have a young lawyers group, the digital assets ecosystem group. And we're just going to go through this evolution that we're going through right now. This is just an evolution of an industry. And the firm is very supportive. I mean, we have our Fin accelerate program, which is an accelerator program focused on supporting fintech companies and digital asset companies. We're also announced on March 8 a challenge around decentralized finance post FTX and frankly, post what happened with the, with the banks that recently. Theres a lot more interest now by investors and market players in decentralized finance. But we know decentralized finance does have massive limitations. The regulators want to be able to speak to somebody if they have concerns. They want to be able to manage things. If someones tokens gets locked and theres nobody to go and reverse it. Coming back to your point about retail, that's a big concern. So DeFi has enormous potential to increase efficiency and financial inclusion, but it requires solutions. And I think solutions such as let's, you know, avoid the regulators, let's try and get around. The regulators isn't going to fly. They're going to shut it down. So we need to come up with solutions. And maybe it can't be completely DeFi. There'll be some DeFi with elements of c five around it. But those kind of solutions need to be developed. And that's why we're launching the DeFi challenge that we launched on March 8. We have huge positive market reaction to it, a lot of interest, and we recommend anyone interested to go to finaccelerate.com. there's a section on the DeFi challenge and to have a read and submit solutions. If you care about the industry and if you care about DeFi's development, submit your solutions.

speaker: A

text: Painful that legally is even a question, because it means that subconsciously this person thinks it might be illegal to control and hold their own assets, which it's not. Right. And that's how used to the idea we've gotten that your assets need to be controlled by someone else. So metamask, I think, is a great place to start in order to have a self sovereign web three wallet that lets you interact with web three applications, or Dapps, then for a more serious solution that's secure and off chain, it's called a cold wallet, as opposed to a hot wallet, you would want to consider a product like ledger and store your crypto on a device. And then what you do with that device is a matter of physical security.

speaker: C
text: All right, so let's get this question also to Abradot. We should say, of course, not financial advice, not legal advice, but general thoughts, abradat, on self custody and doing so. Go ahead.

speaker: E
text: If it's your own assets, you can custody your own assets. There's no legal issue with custody and controlling your own assets. It's only when you actually have third parties holding your assets that the regulation becomes relevant. Now, if we're talking about, and it depends on what the custodian is holding, if the custodian is holding something that's a regulated financial instrument, they need to comply with the relevant regulations. But self custody is basically you just holding your own assets, and there's no issues with that. And Amanda mentioned a few options there. There are other options. The big issue with self custody, of course, is always around loss of keys. And if people die or something happens that they want to leave that for their successes, et cetera, that's the big issue. Or if they forget their password or whatever, that's the main issue around self custody.
